title: Macron finds himself locked in an icy face-off with the political parties he loathes
summary: The French president, who rejected the left's PM candidate, has had a bad relationship with parties for 10 years. The possible appointment of a technocrat would be a new attempt to bypass them, writes political columnist Solenn de Royer.

title: Fears of stronger crackdown grow in Venezuela after Maduro appoints loyalist as interior minister
summary: The hardliner has long been considered the second most powerful person in the country. Rights groups fear it will worsen the government's heavy handed response to protests.

title: Macron faces resistance and struggles to launch new talks to form government
summary: The French President has been forced to contend with the left's refusal to take part in talks after rejecting the candidate it put forward for prime minister. The leftist alliance is the largest bloc in parliament following July's snap elections.

title: Harris will give first interview since becoming Democratic nominee
summary: The current vice president has been criticized for not sitting down with journalists or holding a press conference since Joe Biden dropped out of the race on July 21.

title: Accessibility of Paris métro in question ahead of Paralympics
summary: The region's president has outlined the transport plan for the Paralympics and set out her ambitions for accessibility of the oldest subway lines. The resigning minister for disability has supported her.

title: Brooklyn's fish pond of discord
summary: Residents of Bedford-Stuyvesant in New York City have placed goldfish in a puddle fed by a fire hydrant. The case is making waves in this historically African-American neighborhood in the throes of gentrification.

title: New UK budget will be 'painful,' says PM Keir Starmer
summary: The UK's Prime Minister Keir Starmer criticized his predecessors' mishandling of the country's finances, warning that there may be tax rises for some in the government's October budget.

title: Why was Pavel Durov arrested in France and what charges could he be facing?
summary: The Telegram founder is being questioned by investigators over possible complicity in serious crimes. He could remain in police custody until Wednesday evening.

title: Five dead in second day of Russian attacks on Ukraine
summary: The overnight attacks came one day after the Kremlin launched one of its largest-ever aerial attacks on Ukraine that battered energy facilities and left several dead.

title: Army says Israeli hostage rescued from Gaza after 10 months
summary: Kaid Farhan Alkadi, a 52-year-old Israeli Bedouin, was abducted by Palestinian militants during the October 7 Hamas attack on Israel, the military said in a statement

title: 'Ikejime' or the Japanese art of putting fish to death
summary: 'Influential Japanese cuisine' (2/6). This slaughtering technique, which causes the animal less suffering and preserves it for longer, is increasingly appealing to French gourmets.

title: In Cuba, repression continues to paralyze civil society
summary: From increased surveillance to imprisonment, the situation for protesters on the island continues to worry many human rights defenders.

title: Oasis announces reunion for tour, ending 15-year hiatus during Gallagher brothers' feud
summary: The Britpop band said they will be performing again in 2025. Tickets for the 14-date tour will go on sale Saturday.

title: After Pavel Durov's arrest, Russia's pro-war Telegram channels are in turmoil
summary: The fate of the messaging platform's boss, who is being prosecuted in France for 12  offenses relating to organized crime, concerns military bloggers, who could lose a powerful communication channel.

title: Arson attack on French synagogue marks turning point in anti-Semitic violence
summary: A synagogue was targeted on Saturday in southern France. The National Anti-Terrorist Prosecutor's Office has taken up the case, the first involving anti-Semitic violence since October 7, 2023.

title: Paris 2024 considers plan B for para-triathlon depending on Seine swimming conditions
summary: The water level is still higher than normal for the summer. Organizers are weighing up having the athletes swim only in the direction of the current to avoid putting them in difficulty.

title: Trump, 'Air Force One' and the president who single-handedly takes down despicable terrorists
summary: 'Trump fictions' (1/6). In this series, Le Monde looks back at the movies and pop culture references that have fed the imagination of the former US president, who's again running for office this year.

title: The common ancestor of all present-day living organisms has been partly deciphered
summary: An international study, published in July, proposes a reconstruction of the genome of the universal ancestor, the tiny cell that lived around four billion years ago. Despite many uncertainties, the researchers have imagined the ecosystem in which LUCA lived.

title: Ready for season two of Paris 2024?
summary: From August 28 to September 8, some 4,400 disabled athletes will be competing in the Paris Paralympic Games. Eleven days of competition that organizers hope will be as successful as the two weeks of the Olympics.

title: Paralympic Games: Interior Ministry and Police Prefecture say there will be significant security measures
summary: Laurent Nuñez, the Paris police prefect, and Gérald Darmanin, the interior minister, have announced a slight decrease in the number of police officers but still a heavy presence.

title: Paralympics 2024: Alexander Ekman orchestrates an opening ceremony that will emphasize concord and harmony
summary: The choreographer is bringing together 140 dancers, including 16 with disabilities, for a large-scale show.

title: First rioter to enter US Capitol on January 6 sentenced to 53 months in prison
summary: In their sentencing memorandum, prosecutors said Michael Sparks, 46, 'helped light the fire that day'.

title: 'Keeping the Olympic cauldron in the Tuileries gardens requires a reasoned and reasonable approach'
summary: What should Paris do with the Olympic cauldron? Pierre Noual, a lawyer specializing in cultural history, analyzes the various options for the future of the hot air balloon.

title: Paris 2024: Why China wins every Paralympic Games
summary: From spotting future talent to creating the world's largest training center for disabled athletes, China has created an effective system to ensure the country's success at the Olympics.

title: 2024 Paralympic Games: Wheelchair-bound in Paris, 'I get a knot in my stomach when I go out'
summary: While the hosting of the Paralympic Games is supposed to improve accessibility for people with reduced mobility, even getting around the capital is a challenge.

title: How the mpox virus is adapting to humans
summary: The virus responsible for mpox is more complex than the one behind Covid-19. It originally developed from animals, but is now adapting genetically to humans, according to researchers.

title: Did Macron have to name a left-wing prime minister? No, but he could have, constitutional expert says
summary: The French president cited 'institutional stability' to justify his decision not to name Lucie Castets. The argument is more political than a 'legal constraint,' Benjamin Morel tells Le Monde in an interview.

title: Israel launches major military operation in West Bank
summary: The Israeli army said it had killed nine Palestinian 'terrorists' in its ongoing operation.

title: US aid is still vital to Afghanistan
summary: Since the withdrawal of its troops from Kabul in the summer of 2021, the US has spent almost $21 billion on aid for Afghanistan. Part of this sum has kept the Taliban regime afloat.

title: Northern India's discriminatory order against Muslim restaurant owners illustrates nationalist drift
summary: On the occasion of the Kanwar Yatra Hindu pilgrimage, officials in the state of Uttar Pradesh told Muslim restaurant owners to display their names to 'protect' pilgrims.

title: In Kyiv, Zelensky presents Ukrainian offensive in Kursk as 'victory plan'
summary: In a rare appearance before the press, the Ukrainian president, in a position of strength, justified the incursion of his armed forces into Russian territory in order to push Moscow to negotiate.

title: Arrested Telegram CEO Pavel Durov met with Macron several times before obtaining French nationality
summary: The French president granted several appointments to the creator of the social media platform, who was arrested in France on Saturday, before he became a French citizen in 2021.

title: What would an impeachment procedure against Macron consist of?
summary: The lengthy mechanism provided for in Article 68 of the Constitution currently has virtually no chance of leading to the removal of the French president from office.

title: UK and Germany plan new treaty as part of post-Brexit 'reset'
summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer and his German counterpart Olaf Scholz agreed on plans for a bilateral treaty, as well as discussing aid for Ukraine and how to crack down on migrant smuggling.

title: Burkina Faso civilians pay ruling junta's anti-jihadist strategy with their lives
summary: Several hundred civilians were killed by jihadists on August 24 in Barsalogho, while digging trenches they had been told by the military regime would protect them.

title: Why the Paralympics' TikTok account is causing controversy
summary: The account, where humorous videos about athletes are posted regularly, has 4.5 million followers and over 1 billion views.

title: Subtle, satisfying and cheap: Ramen is a slurpable phenomenon
summary: 'Influential Japanese cuisine' (3/6). This simmering emblem of Japanese gastronomy has spread far beyond its borders. Now, with heads over their bowls, everyone slurps and says 'ramen' in all its forms, even in the land of the pot-roast chicken!

title: US announces sanctions on Israeli settlers carrying out violence against Palestinians
summary: The US has imposed sanctions on Israeli settlers in the West Bank who have been setting up roadblocks, forcing Palestinians to leave their homes and attacking them.
